awd_titl_txt: Strong Interactions, Topology, and Constraints in Emerging Phases of Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports research and education towards understanding the properties of new phases of matter in three dimensions, and the dynamics of low-dimensional quantum systems. One of the frontiers of modern physics is understanding what new types of quantum phenomena can occur in systems with many interacting particles. Striking examples of such phenomena discovered in the 20th century include superfluidity, superconductivity, and the fractional quantum Hall effect, all of which entail macroscopic numbers of interacting particles entering a coherent quantum state. More recently, rapid progress in our understanding of how specific abstract properties (in technical terms, topological properties) of quantum many-particle systems influence their real physical properties has led to the discovery of new classes of materials, such as topological insulators and superconductors. The latter, in particular, have drawn interest as a potential platform for quantum computing, in which information can be stored in a way that is intrinsically robust to random noise.

The research focuses on two themes that are of current interest both for expanding our understanding of new types of possible quantum phenomena, and for investigating how strong interactions can potentially help identify promising platforms for quantum computing. The first theme is expanding our understanding of how topological properties can lead to new types of interacting quantum matter in three dimensions. The second theme is understanding how strong interactions, and ultimately the kinds of topological properties that are already well-understood in these systems, help shape how quantum systems evolve in time at finite temperature.

The project will contribute to the workforce of highly trained STEM professionals both by training graduate students, and through programs and events coordinated by the PI focused on facilitating the transition of interested physics undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Minnesota to jobs in the private sector. This includes working with engineering departments to allow interested physics undergraduates to participate in senior engineering design projects, as well as helping coordinate extracurricular networking and career-information events aimed specifically at physics students.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports research and education towards understanding the role of topology and constraints in two areas: new phases of matter in three dimensions, and the dynamics of low-dimensional systems. 

In the area of phases of matter in three dimensions, the proposed research will focus on recently discovered fracton phases of matter, with the unusual feature that their low-lying excitations have restricted mobility. A combination of field-theoretic techniques and tools for analyzing group cohomology developed in the study of interacting symmetry-protected phases of matter will be used to address the following questions. First, what field theories exhibit the qualitative features of fracton phases? Second, when does symmetry in these and related systems lead to protected gapless boundary modes?  Addressing these questions will expand our understanding of how the interplay between geometry and topology in these systems leads to physical properties qualitatively unlike those of other three-dimensional quantum phases.

In the area of dynamics in low-dimensional systems, the focus will be on exploring the impact of constraints and topological order on dynamics. The proposed research will use a combination of numerical (exact diagonalization) and analytical approaches based in perturbation theory and random-matrix theory. As low-dimensional systems that approximate constrained systems become experimentally accessible, clarifying whether, when, and how constraints can lead to unusually slow dynamics in quantum many-body systems can significantly advance our understanding of how information can be more robustly stored at intermediate time-scales in quantum many-body systems. 

The project will contribute to the workforce of highly trained STEM professionals both by training graduate students, and through programs and events coordinated by the PI focused on facilitating the transition of interested physics undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Minnesota to jobs in the private sector. This includes working with engineering departments to allow interested physics undergraduates to participate in senior engineering design projects, as well as helping coordinate extracurricular networking and career-information events aimed specifically at physics students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported research into two somewhat distinct questions, which are related through their ties to quantum information theory.  The first question is, under what conditions might we find at surfaces or boundaries of a system robust quantum states that cannot be destroyed by sample impurities or other real-world imperfections?  This topic has been of considerable interest for the past 15 years, as such states are potentially useful for a range of applications, including for both classical and quantum hardware.  The project explored new directions in this vein, including how conservation laws that have a geometrical character can lead to new classes of states of this type, as well as how cousins of these states can have meaningful implications for systems under active experimental study, such as one-dimensional dipolar arrays, and (quadrupolar) Weyl semi-metals.  It also showed how well-established tools (field theories) can be modified to describe these classes of systems, providing an important part of the play-book for further work in this direction.  

Related research also made advances in the area of topological order, which allows quantum information to be stored non-locally in the bulk of a system, as well as proposing experimental probes (known as quantum games) that could be used to diagnose the existence of this information in a real quantum processor.  

The second question is, when a quantum-mechanical system is allowed to evolve in time, when does it do so in a way that defies the expectations of statistical mechanics?  This question is particularly timely as researchers strive to find new ways to store information in quantum systems over long periods of time: statistical mechanics predicts that information that is initially stored lcoally in a many-particle system rapidly becomes irretrievable, as it is delocalized in a complex way across all of the particles.  An interesting class of systems for which this does not happen are so-called quantum many-body scars -- in these models, some specific initial states retain an (in principle) infinitely long-time memory, with the exact initial state recurring periodically at predictable times.  The project supported research that (1) described a general mechanism that can lead to such quantum scars, which allowed the PI and co-authors to obtain several new examples of systems that realize this behavior, and (2) outlined a specific experimental set-up in which the surprising recurrences of these scarred models are provably robust to experimental noise and imprefections up to moderately long times (though in realistic experiments, the memory is never infinitely long-lived).  Related research considered similarly unusual longevity in processes involving energy relaxation in constrained open quantum systems.  

Finally, the project supported a number of educational activities.  A primary focus was the development of a course on quantum computing and quantum information, which is now being taught regularly in the physics department at UMN.  As interest both within academia and the private sector in quanutm computing grows, it is beneficial to both graduate and undergraduate students to have a course outlining the basic tools and principles of this field.  To serve the needs of students actively performing research in this area, the PI also co-organized a summer school at the University of Minnesota in June of 2023 on the closely related area of quantum dynamics and quantum information.  

The PI was also active in helping to establish a career advisory board for the UMN physics department, with the goal of creating better connections between both undergraduate and PhD students seeking employment in the private sector, and companies that are potentially interested in hiring them, as well as of preparing these students for an effective job search.
